text: In the very early days, people will discount till the cows come home because they think that's the way to get a deal done. The best clients are not going to do that to you. If they're sitting there nickel-and-diming you, they're not fully bought in on what you're selling them.
speaker: Jen Abel
context: Lenny mentions that most founders would rather get 10 ten-thousand-dollar deals than lose nine and get one hundred-thousand-dollar deal. Jen explains why this approach is problematic for enterprise sales. She argues that discounting heavily signals weakness and attracts the wrong type of clients who aren't truly committed to the product's value.
vocabulary_highlights: discount till the cows come home
text_ko: 초기에는 많은 사람이 거래를 성사시키려고 끝없이 할인을 해요(discount till the cows come home). 그게 딜을 성사시키는 방법이라고 생각하니까요. 하지만 최고의 고객들은 그렇게 하지 않아요. 만약 고객이 계속 꼬투리 잡아 한 푼씩 깎으려 한다면(nickel-and-diming), 그건 당신이 제안하는 것에 완전히 공감하고 투자한 상태가 아니라고 볼 수 있어요(fully bought in).
text_zh: 刚开始做生意的时候，很多人会拼命砍价，觉得这样才能成交。但真正的好客户不会这么折腾你。如果他们老是跟你斤斤计较，抠这个抠那个的，说明他们根本就没真心想买你的东西。
text_es: En los primeros días, la gente va a regatear hasta el cansancio porque creen que así es como se cierra un trato. Los mejores clientes no te van a hacer eso. Si están ahí regateándote cada centavo, es porque no están realmente convencidos de lo que les estás vendiendo.

text: As soon as you become a comparison, as soon as you become one of three that they're testing out, you've already sort of lost. It's all about differentiation. Here's what you will be able to do tomorrow because of how we're going to serve you today.
speaker: Jen Abel
context: Jen is explaining how to position your product in enterprise sales. She emphasizes that once a potential client starts comparing your solution to others in a competitive evaluation process, you've lost your advantage. The key is to differentiate yourself by focusing on future opportunities and outcomes rather than competing on features or price.
text_ko: 비교 대상이 되거나 그들이 시험해보는 세 후보 중 하나로 여겨지는 순간, 이미 어느 정도 불리해요. 핵심은 차별화(differentiation)이에요. 오늘 우리가 어떻게 서비스를 제공하느냐에 따라 내일 무엇을 할 수 있게 될지가 결정돼요. 그래서 우리가 오늘 이렇게 해드리면, 내일은 이렇게 하실 수 있어요.
text_zh: 一旦你变成了被比较的对象，一旦你成了他们要测试的三个选择之一，基本上就已经输了。关键在于差异化(differentiation)。要让客户知道：因为我们今天为你提供的服务，明天你就能做到这些事情。
text_es: En cuanto te conviertes en una opción más para comparar, en cuanto te vuelves uno de los tres que están evaluando, ya prácticamente perdiste. Todo se trata de diferenciación. Esto es lo que vas a poder lograr mañana gracias a cómo te vamos a atender hoy.

text: Enterprise is the number one thing they buy services, they know how to do it's super easy, they do it all of the time. It's like the most consistent thing they do. It's their largest budget item, external resources, consultants, whatever.
speaker: Jen Abel
context: Lenny asks about Jen's advice to start with services rather than just selling software products to enterprises. Jen explains that large companies are very comfortable buying services and consulting - it's something they do regularly and have large budgets for. This makes services an easier entry point than trying to sell new technology solutions.
text_ko: 기업(enterprise)은 서비스 구매가 가장 큰 비중이에요. 어떻게 하는지 잘 알고 있어서 아주 손쉽게 처리해요. 늘 하던 일이니까요. 가장 일관되게 하는 활동이고, 예산도 가장 큰 항목이에요. 외부 리소스(external resources)나 컨설턴트(consultants) 같은 데에 많이 쓰여요.
text_zh: 大企业买服务这事儿是他们的强项，轻车熟路的，天天都在做。这是他们最稳定的操作了，也是预算里最大的一块 - 外部资源啊、咨询啊什么的。
text_es: Las empresas grandes son las que más compran servicios, ya saben cómo hacerlo y es súper fácil para ellas, lo hacen todo el tiempo. Es como lo más constante que hacen. Es su partida presupuestaria más grande: recursos externos, consultores, lo que sea.

text: It's more of an art. It's all about deal crafting. It is a relationship you're building with someone. If they know they can call on you, people will turn over rocks for you. I have a client at a Fortune 10 company where I was like, 'It's so important we get the deal done this year. Is that possible?' And she's like, 'It's a tall order, but if it's going to help you, let's do it.' These are how enterprise deals gets done. It's relationships.
speaker: Jen Abel
context: Lenny mentions that Jen talks about enterprise sales being very creative. Jen responds by explaining that enterprise sales is more of an art than a science, requiring creativity in structuring deals and building deep relationships. She shares a real example of how a strong relationship with a Fortune 10 client led them to expedite a deal specifically to help her, demonstrating the power of relationship-based selling.
text_ko: 이건 더 예술에 가까워요. 결국은 딜 구성(deal crafting)이 핵심이에요. 누군가와 쌓아가는 관계예요. 상대가 필요할 때 도움을 요청해도 된다고 알면, 사람들은 발품까지 팔아가며 도와줘요. 포춘 10대 기업(Fortune 10 company)의 고객이 한 분 있는데 제가 “올해 이 딜을 꼭 마무리하는 게 중요해요. 가능할까요?”라고 물었더니 그분이 “무리한 요청이긴 하지만, 당신에게 도움이 된다면 해보죠”라고 하더라고요. 엔터프라이즈 딜(enterprise deals)은 이렇게 관계로 성사돼요. 결국 관계예요.
text_zh: 这更像是一门艺术。关键在于怎么做交易(deal crafting)。你其实是在跟人建立关系。如果他们知道有事能找你，别人就会为你想方设法。我有个客户在世界500强前10的公司，我跟她说："今年把这单搞定对我们特别重要，有可能吗？"她就说："要求是挺高的，但如果能帮到你，那咱们就干吧。"企业级交易(enterprise deals)就是这么成的，靠的就是关系。
text_es: Es más un arte, ¿sabes? Todo se trata de construir el negocio (deal crafting). Lo que estás haciendo es crear una relación con alguien. Si saben que pueden contar contigo, la gente va a mover cielo y tierra por ti. Tengo una cliente en una empresa Fortune 10 donde le dije, 'Es súper importante que cerremos este negocio este año. ¿Será posible?' Y me dice, 'Está complicado, pero si te va a ayudar, hagámoslo.' Así es como se cierran los negocios grandes (enterprise deals). Todo son relaciones.

text: I want to email someone not in the database that's getting hit by a million folks. I want to take a back door in, not the front door where everyone else is trick or treating.
speaker: Jen Abel
context: Lenny asks about the state of the art in go-to-market outbound tooling. Jen explains why she doesn't use automated tools for prospecting. She believes that AI tools and databases are creating too much noise because they all target the same people. Instead, she prefers finding unique ways to reach prospects that others aren't using.
text_ko: 데이터베이스(database)가 이미 수많은 사람들에게 시달리고 있어서, 그 안에 없는 사람에게 이메일을 보내고 싶어요. 다들 우르르 몰려가는 앞문(front door)으로 가지 않고 백도어(back door)로 슬쩍 들어가고 싶어요.
text_zh: 我想给数据库里没有的人发邮件，不想走那些被无数人轰炸的渠道。我要走后门，不走正门——正门那儿人太多了，跟要糖的小孩似的排着队呢。
text_es: Quiero contactar por email a alguien que no está en la base de datos pero que está siendo bombardeado por un millón de personas. Quiero entrar por la puerta de atrás, no por la puerta principal donde todos están pidiendo dulces.

text: The market doesn't want to be sold to, they want to buy. And I know that it's very hard to hire a really good enterprise salesperson. The number of people that I've interviewed, I can count on my hand the ones that I get really, really excited by.
speaker: Jen Abel
context: Jen is discussing what makes a good enterprise salesperson and why it's challenging to find the right people. She explains that taking typical salespeople and putting them in startup sales roles often fails because it feels too 'salesy' to prospects. She emphasizes that great enterprise salespeople are as rare as great founders or engineers.
text_ko: 시장은 누군가에게 일방적으로 팔리기를 원하지 않고, 스스로 사기를 원해요. 그리고 진짜 좋은 엔터프라이즈 영업 담당자(enterprise salesperson)를 뽑는 건 정말 어렵다는 걸 잘 알아요. 제가 면접 본 사람들 중에서 정말로 기대가 되고 가슴이 뛰었던 사람은 손에 꼽을 정도예요.
text_zh: 市场不想被推销，他们想要主动购买。我知道招到一个真正优秀的企业销售特别难。我面试过那么多人，真正让我眼前一亮的，用一只手都能数得过来。
text_es: El mercado no quiere que le vendan, quiere comprar. Y sé que es súper difícil contratar a un vendedor empresarial realmente bueno. De toda la gente que he entrevistado, puedo contar con los dedos de una mano a los que realmente me emocionan.
